inference:
The angle $PQS$ is $136^\circ$.
The angle $RQS$ is $64^\circ$.
The sum of angles on a straight line is $180^\circ$.
The angle $PQR$ is $180^\circ$.
$136^\circ + 64^\circ = 200^\circ$.
The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
The triangle $QRS$ has an exterior angle $x^\circ$.
The interior angles of the triangle $QRS$ are $x^\circ$, $64^\circ$ and $90^\circ$.
$x^\circ = 64^\circ + (180^\circ-136^\circ)$.
The sum of the angles in a triangle is $180^\circ$.
$\angle QRS = 180^\circ - 136^\circ = 44^\circ$.
$\angle SQR = 136^\circ$
$\angle QRS = 64^\circ$
$\angle QRS + \angle SQR + \angle RSQ = 180^\circ$
$64^\circ + 136^\circ + \angle RSQ = 180^\circ$
$200^\circ + \angle RSQ = 180^\circ$
$ \angle RSQ$ is not $180^\circ - (136^\circ+64^\circ) = -180^\circ$, no valid triangle formed.

In triangle $QRS$, $\angle SQR = 136^\circ$.
The exterior angle $x$ of the triangle $QRS$ at $S$ is equal to the sum of the non-adjacent interior angles.
$x = \angle QRS + \angle SQR$
$x = 64^\circ + (180^\circ - 136^\circ)$
$x = 64^\circ + 44^\circ$
$x = 108^\circ$

Final Answer: $\boxed{108}$
ground_truth: Since $\angle PQS$ is an exterior angle of $\triangle QRS$, then $\angle PQS=\angle QRS+\angle QSR$, so $136^\circ = x^\circ + 64^\circ$ or $x = 136-64=\boxed{72}$.

$\angle PQR = \angle PQS + \angle RQS = 136^\circ + 64^\circ = 200^\circ$
The sum of angles around a point is $360^\circ$.  This is not a problem in the given data.
$\angle PQR = \angle PQS + \angle RQS = 136^\circ + 64^\circ = 200^\circ$.
The sum of the angles in a triangle is $180^\circ$.
In triangle $QRS$,
$\angle QRS = 180^\circ - (\angle PQS - \angle RQS) = 180^\circ - (136^\circ - 64^\circ) = 180^\circ - 72^\circ = 108^\circ$
The angle $x$ is an exterior angle of the triangle $QRS$.  Therefore, $x$ is the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
$x = 64^\circ + \angle RSQ$.
Also, $\angle PQR = \angle PQS + \angle RQS = 136^\circ + 64^\circ = 200^\circ$

$\angle PQS + \angle SQR = 180^\circ$
$\angle SQR = 180^\circ - 136^\circ = 44^\circ$.
In $\triangle QRS$, we have
$\angle QRS + 44^\circ + 64^\circ = 180^\circ$
$\angle QRS + 108^\circ = 180^\circ$
$\angle QRS = 72^\circ$.
$x = 64^\circ + \angle QRS = 64^\circ + 72^\circ = 136^\circ$.
In $\triangle QRS$,
$\angle QRS + \angle RSQ + \angle SQR = 180^\circ$
Exterior angle at $S = \angle PQS = 136^\circ$.
$136^\circ = 64^\circ + \angle RSQ$
$\angle RSQ = 72^\circ$
$x = 64^\circ + 72^\circ = 136^\circ$.
In $\triangle QRS$, exterior angle $x = \angle PQS = 136^\circ$
$\angle QRS = 180^\circ - (64^\circ + 44^\circ) = 180^\circ - 108^\circ = 72^\circ$
$x = 64^\circ + 72^\circ = 136^\circ$.

The exterior angle is the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
$x = 64^\circ + 44^\circ = 108^\circ$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{108}$
ground_truth: Since $\angle PQS$ is an exterior angle of $\triangle QRS$, then $\angle PQS=\angle QRS+\angle QSR$, so $136^\circ = x^\circ + 64^\circ$ or $x = 136-64=\boxed{72}$.
